description:
Thryonomys swinderianus, commonly known as the greater cane rat or grasscutter, is a species of rodent found in Africa. It belongs to the family Thryonomyidae, which are large, semi-aquatic rodents adapted to living in dense grasslands and wetlands.

The greater cane rat is a robust, heavy-bodied animal with short, stout limbs and a broad, blunt head. It can grow up to 60 cm in length and weigh up to 9 kg. Its fur is coarse and grizzled in appearance, ranging from reddish-brown to gray. The tail is short and scaly.

These rodents are herbivorous, feeding primarily on grasses, sedges, and other aquatic vegetation. They are known for their ability to swim and their tendency to live in burrows or nests constructed in dense vegetation near water sources.

Greater cane rats are widespread across sub-Saharan Africa, ranging from Senegal to Ethiopia and as far south as South Africa. They are an important source of bushmeat and are also farmed in some regions for their meat and fur.

Conservation-wise, the greater cane rat is classified as a Least Concern species by the IUCN, as it is generally abundant throughout its range and has adapted well to human-modified environments.
